revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Death In Brunswick]]
#REDIRECT [[Death in Brunswick]]
#REDIRECT [[Death in Brunswick]] {{R from other capitalisation}}

'''''Tous les garçons s'appellent Patrick''''' ([[1958]]) was the third of four short fiction films made by French filmmaker [[Jean-Luc Godard]], before he began his work in feature-length, narrative film.
{{film-stub}}

revision.comment: replace with a (sourced) stub on the actual fim in the title

{{Infobox_Film | name = Une histoire d'eau | image = | imdb_id = 0050714| director = [[François Truffaut]]
[[Jean-Luc Godard]] | writer = [[François Truffaut]]
[[Jean-Luc Godard]] | starring = [[Jean-Claude Brialy]]
[[Caroline Dim]]
[[Jean-Luc Godard]] (narration) | released = [[March 3]], [[1961 in film|1961]] | runtime = 18 min. | language = [[French]] | }} '''Une histoire d'eau'''(aka A Story of Water) is a film directed and written by [[Jean-Luc Godard]] and [[François Truffaut]] in 1961. It recounts the story of a woman's trip to Paris, which is surrounded by a large flooded area. ==Sources== {{imdb title|id=0052338|title=Une histoire d'eau}} {{short-film-stub}} [[it:Une histoire d'eau]]

Jean-Luc Godard | starring = [[Jean-Claude Brialy]]
[[Caroline Dim]]| released = March 3, 1961 | runtime = 18 min | language = [[French language|French]] | }} '''''A Story of Water''''' ({{lang-fr|Une histoire d'eau}}) is a film directed and written by [[Jean-Luc Godard]] and [[François Truffaut]] in [[1961 in film|1961]]. It recounts the story of a woman's trip to [[Paris]], which is surrounded by a large flooded area. The title is a [[pun]] on the title of the [[erotic literature#erotic fiction|erotic novel]] [[Story of O|Une histoire d'O]]. It is included as a supplement on [[Criterion|Criterion's]] [[DVD]]/[[BluRay]] release of Truffaut's ''[[The Last Metro]]''. ==External links== * {{Imdb title|id=0052338|title=Une histoire d'eau}} {{Godard}} {{Truffaut}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Story Of Water, A}} [[Category:1961 films]] [[Category:Black-and-white films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Short films]] [[Category:Films directed by Jean-Luc Godard]] [[Category:Films directed by François Truffaut]] {{short-film-stub}} [[et:Une histoire d'eau]] [[fr:Une histoire d'eau]] [[it:Une histoire d'eau]] [[ja:水の話]] [[pt:Une histoire d'eau]]

{{Infobox film | name = A Story of Water | image = File:Une Histoire D'Eau poster.jpg | image_size = 225px | caption = poster | director = [[François Truffaut]]
[[Jean-Luc Godard]] | producer = [[Pierre Braunberger]] | writer = François Truffaut | narrator = Caroline Dim | starring = [[Jean-Claude Brialy]]
Caroline Dim | cinematography = Michel Latouche | editing = Jean-Luc Godard | studio = Les Films de la Pléiade | distributor = Unidex | released = March 3, 1961 ''(France)'' | runtime = 12 minutes | language = [[French language|French]] }} '''''A Story of Water''''' ({{lang-fr|Une histoire d'eau}}) is a [[short film]] directed and written by [[Jean-Luc Godard]] and [[François Truffaut]] in [[1958 in film|1958]]. It recounts the story of a woman's trip to [[Paris]], which is surrounded by a large flooded area. It was first shown publicly in 1961. The title is a [[pun]] on the title of the [[erotic literature#Erotic fiction|erotic novel]] ''[[Story of O|Une histoire d'O]]''. The film was shot in two days. According to film critic [[David Edelstein]], introducing the film's presentation on [[TCM.com]], Truffaut's screenplay was a "slight but reasonably coherent romance" which was altered significantly in the editing room by Goddard, who added [[absurdism|absurdist]] [[voiceover]]s and percussion music while cutting out most of the the plot.Edelstein, David. Intro to ''A Story of Water'' on [[TCM.com]] (July 19, 2013) The film is included as a supplement on [[The Criterion Collection|Criterion's]] [[DVD]]/[[Blu-ray]] release of Truffaut's ''[[The Last Metro]]''. ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0052338|title=Une histoire d'eau}}\ {{short-film-stub}} {{1950s-France-film-stub}} {{Godard}} {{Truffaut}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Story Of Water, A}} [[Category:1958 films]] [[Category:Black-and-white films]] [[Category:Films directed by François Truffaut]] [[Category:Films directed by Jean-Luc Godard]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:French short films]]

Caroline Dim | cinematography = Michel Latouche | editing = Jean-Luc Godard | studio = Les Films de la Pléiade | distributor = Unidex | released = March 3, 1961 ''(France)'' | runtime = 12 minutes | language = [[French language|French]] }} '''''A Story of Water''''' ({{lang-fr|Une histoire d'eau}}) is a [[short film]] directed and written by [[Jean-Luc Godard]] and [[François Truffaut]] in [[1958 in film|1958]]. It recounts the story of a woman's trip to [[Paris]], which is surrounded by a large flooded area. It was first shown publicly in 1961. The title is a [[pun]] on the title of the [[erotic literature#Erotic fiction|erotic novel]] ''[[Story of O|Une histoire d'O]]''. The film was shot in two days. According to film critic [[David Edelstein]], introducing the film's presentation on [[TCM.com]], Truffaut's screenplay was a "slight but reasonably coherent romance" which was altered significantly in the editing room by Godard, who added [[absurdism|absurdist]] [[voiceover]]s and percussion music while cutting out most of the plot.Edelstein, David. Intro to ''A Story of Water'' on [[TCM.com]] (July 19, 2013) The film is included as a supplement on [[The Criterion Collection|Criterion's]] [[DVD]]/[[Blu-ray]] release of Truffaut's ''[[The Last Metro]]''. ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0052338|title=Une histoire d'eau}}\ {{Godard}} {{Truffaut}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Story Of Water, A}} [[Category:1958 films]] [[Category:Black-and-white films]] [[Category:Films directed by François Truffaut]] [[Category:Films directed by Jean-Luc Godard]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:French short films]] {{short-film-stub}} {{1950s-France-film-stub}}

The unit comprises of officers from all unit and are trained on tactical training.

[[category:Toronto Police Service]]

A tactial unit of the [[Toronto Police Service]] to deal with high risk situations like gun calls, hostage taking. The unit was created in [[1965]].
The unit comprises of 70 officers from all unit and are trained on tactical training.
The unit is located in [[Don Mills, Ontario]] at 35,000 square foot building built in [[1989]]:
* meeting rooms * two shooting ranges * rappelling tower * exercise room
==See Also==
* [[Police Tactical Unit]] and [[Special Duties Unit]] of the [[Hong Kong Police]] * [[Special Air Service|SAS]] * German [[GSG-9]]
==External links== * [http://www.torontopolice.on.ca/etf/ ETF] * [http://www.torontopolice.on.ca Toronto Police]

{{expansion}} A tactial unit of the [[Toronto Police Service]] to deal with high risk situations like gun calls, hostage taking. The unit was created in [[1965]].

* meeting rooms * two shooting ranges * rappelling tower * exercise room
A tactial unit of the Toronto Police Service to deal with high risk situations like gun calls, hostage taking, barricaded persons, emotional disturbed persons, high risk arrest and protection details. The unit was created in 1965.
The unit comprises of 70 officers from all unit and are trained on tactical training. There are six tactical teams with nine officers each. Each tactical team has a team leader, sniper, negotiator / emotional disturbed persons expert. All team members are also considered assaulters, who are trained to go into a premise and rescue any hostage(s) and arrest or neutralize any suspect(s)
The unit is located in Don Mills, Ontario at 35,000 square foot building built in 1989:
meeting rooms two shooting ranges rappelling tower exercise room large garage to house the units specialized vehicles
The Emergency Task Force (E.T.F) is the unit which three of the police services specialized units fall into. The special weapons teams (tactical), explosive disposal unit (E.D.U), and the emergency response unit (E.R.U) which provides speciallized equipment to the service (high powered lights, crane, mobile command post).
The team does training not only at their station in Don Mills, but also at C.F.B Borden, a military base about forty five minutes north of the city.
==See also==
* [[Police Tactical Unit]] and [[Special Duties Unit]] of the [[Hong Kong Police]] * [[Special Air Service|SAS]] * German [[GSG 9]]
==External links== * [http://www.torontopolice.on.ca/etf/ Official website] * [http://www.torontopolice.on.ca Toronto Police]

The unit comprises of 70 officers from all unit and are trained on tactical training. There are six tactical teams with nine officers each. meeting rooms two shooting ranges rappelling tower exercise room large garage to house the units specialized vehicles

The team does training not only at their station in Don Mills, but also at C.F.B Borden, a military base about forty five minutes north of the city.
There are six tactical teams with nine officers each. Each tactical team has a team leader, sniper, negotiator / emotional disturbed persons expert. All team members are also considered assaulters, who are trained to go into a premise and rescue any hostage(s) and arrest or neutralize any suspect(s)
The Emergency Task Force (E.T.F) is the unit which three of the police services specialized units fall into. The special weapons teams (tactical), explosive disposal unit (E.D.U), and the emergency response unit (E.R.U) which provides speciallized equipment to the service (high powered lights, crane, mobile command post).
The team does training not only at their station in Don Mills, but also at C.F.B Borden, a military base about forty five minutes north of the city. The unit also trains with members of the Canadian Military, in particular it's special forces / anti-terrorism unit Joint Task Force Two (J.T.F-2)

[[category:Toronto Police Service]]

{{expansion}} A tactial unit of the Toronto Police Service to deal with high risk situations like gun calls, hostage taking, barricaded persons, emotional disturbed persons, high risk arrest and protection details. The unit was created in [[1965]].
The unit comprises of 70 officers from all unit and are trained on tactical training. There are nine officers to each tactical team. Each tactical team has a team leader, sniper, negotiator / emotional disturbed persons expert. All team members are also considered assaulters, who are trained to go into a premise and rescue any hostage(s) and arrest or neutralize any suspect(s)
The unit is located in [[Don Mills, Ontario]] at 35,000 square foot building built in [[1989]]:
* meeting rooms * two shooting ranges * rappelling tower * exercise room * large garage to house the units speciallized vehicles
The Emergency Task Force (E.T.F) is the unit which three of the police services specialized units fall into. The special weapons teams (tactical), explosive disposal unit (E.D.U), and the emergency response unit (E.R.U) which provides speciallized equipment to the service (high powered lights, crane, mobile command post).
The E.T.F utilizes Glock semi-automatic pistols as their sidearm. Officers also have the the Heckler & Koch MP-5 9mm submachine gun and the C8, which is the Canandian version of the M-4 carbine, firing a .223 caliber round. Less than lethal options are also at the disposal of team members such as Tasers, Pepper Spray (OC Spray) and Tear Gas (CS Gas) and Rubber Bullets.
The main vehicles used by the team include Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptors and G.M.C Surburbans. The E.T.F also has an armoured car in their garage which can be used to rescue injured civlians or officers.
The team does training not only at their station in Don Mills, but also at C.F.B Borden, a military base about forty five minutes north of the city. The unit also trains with members of the Canadian Military, in particular it's special forces / anti-terrorism unit Joint Task Force Two (J.T.F-2) who work out of the Dwyer Hill Training Facility outside of Ottawa.
==See also==
* [[Police Tactical Unit]] and [[Special Duties Unit]] of the [[Hong Kong Police]] * [[Special Air Service|SAS]] * German [[GSG 9]]
==External links== * [http://www.torontopolice.on.ca/etf/ Official website] * [http://www.torontopolice.on.ca Toronto Police]

Each tactical team has a team leader, sniper, negotiator / emotionally disturbed persons expert. All team members are also considered assaulters, who are trained to go into a premise and rescue any hostage(s) and arrest or neutralize any suspect(s)
The unit is located in [[Don Mills, Ontario]] at 35,000 square foot building built in [[1989]]:
* meeting rooms * two shooting ranges * rappelling tower * exercise room * large garage to house the units specialized vehicles
The Emergency Task Force (E.T.F) is the unit which three of the police services specialized units fall into. The special weapons teams (tactical), explosive disposal unit (E.D.U), and the emergency response unit (E.R.U) which provides specialized equipment to the service (high powered lights, crane, mobile command post).
The E.T.F utilizes Glock semi-automatic pistols as their sidearm. Officers also have the the Heckler & Koch MP-5 9mm submachine gun and the C8, which is the Canandian version of the M-4 carbine, firing a .223 caliber round. Less than lethal options are also at the disposal of team members such as Tasers, Pepper Spray (OC Spray) and Tear Gas (CS Gas) and Rubber Bullets.
The main vehicles used by the team include Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptors and G.M.C Surburbans. The E.T.F also has an armoured car in their garage which can be used to rescue injured civlians or officers.
The team does training not only at their station in Don Mills, but also at C.F.B Borden, a military base about 45 minutes north of the city. The unit also trains with members of the Canadian Military, in particular it's special forces / anti-terrorism unit Joint Task Force Two (J.T.F-2) who work out of the Dwyer Hill Training Facility outside of Ottawa.

{{expansion}} A tactical unit of the Toronto Police Service to deal with high risk situations like gun calls, hostage taking, barricaded persons, emotionally disturbed persons, high risk arrest and protection details. The unit was created in [[1965]].
==Organization== The unit's current commander is Staff Inspector James Ramer. Emergency Task Force currently comprises of 70 officers from all units and are trained on tactical training. There are nine officers to each tactical team. Each tactical team has a team leader, sniper, negotiator / emotionally disturbed persons expert. All team members are also considered assaulters, who are trained to go into a premise and rescue any hostage(s) and arrest or neutralize any suspect(s)

[[category:Toronto Police Service]] [[Category:Special forces of Canada]]

{{expansion}} A tactical unit of the Toronto Police Service to deal with high risk situations like gun calls, hostage taking, barricaded persons, emotionally disturbed persons, high risk arrest and protection details. The unit was created in [[1965]].
==Organization== The unit's current commander is Staff Inspector James Ramer. Emergency Task Force currently comprises of 70 officers from all units and are trained on tactical training. There are nine officers to each tactical team. Each tactical team has a team leader, sniper, negotiator / emotionally disturbed persons expert. All team members are also considered assaulters, who are trained to go into a premise and rescue any hostage(s) and arrest or neutralize any suspect(s)
The unit is located in [[Don Mills, Ontario]] at 35,000 square foot building built in [[1989]]:
* meeting rooms * two shooting ranges * rappelling tower * exercise room * large garage to house the units specialized vehicles
The Emergency Task Force (E.T.F) is the unit which three of the police services specialized units fall into. The special weapons teams (tactical), explosive disposal unit (E.D.U), and the emergency response unit (E.R.U) which provides specialized equipment to the service (high powered lights, crane, mobile command post).
The team does training not only at their station in Don Mills, but also at C.F.B Borden, a military base about 45 minutes north of the city. The unit also trains with members of the Canadian Military, in particular it's special forces / anti-terrorism unit Joint Task Force Two (J.T.F-2) which works out of the Dwyer Hill Training Facility outside of Ottawa.
The E.T.F. also has a close working relationship with other police tactical teams in the Greater Toronto Area, such as the York Regional Police Emergency Response Unit (E.R.U), the Durham Regional Police Tactical Support Unit (T.S.U) and the Peel Regional Police Tactical and Rescue Unit (T.R.U).
==Equipment== The E.T.F utilizes Glock semi-automatic pistols as their sidearm. Officers also have the the Heckler & Koch MP5 9mm submachine gun, Remington 700 sniper rifle, (which fires a 7.62mm round), Remington 870 shotgun, and the Diemaco C8, which is the Canadian version of the Colt M4 carbine, firing a .223 caliber round. Less than lethal options are also at the disposal of team members such as the M18 and X26 Tasers, Pepper Spray (OC Spray) and Tear Gas (CS Gas) and Rubber Bullets or BeanBags rounds.
The main vehicles used by the team include Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptors and G.M.C Surburbans. The E.T.F also has an armoured car in their garage which can be used to rescue injured civlians or officers.

Officers also have the [[Heckler & Koch]] [[MP5]] 9mm submachine gun, [[Remington 700]] sniper rifle, Remington 870 shotgun, Mossberg M500 and the [[M4 Carbine]] series of rifles, including the M16; [[Barrett M82A1]]. Less than lethal options are also at the disposal of team members such as the M18 and X26 Tasers, Pepper Spray (OC Spray) and Tear Gas (CS Gas) and Rubber Bullets or BeanBags rounds.
The main vehicles used by the team include Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptors and G.M.C Surburbans. The E.T.F also has an armoured car in their garage which can be used to rescue injured civlians or officers. The current armoured car was put into service about a year and half ago (January 2007).
Some police tactical teams have a police helicopter at their disposal. The helicopter can be used as a method of inserting team members, gathering valuable intelligence, acting as a position for a sniper/observer team and to also act as a distraction for an assault team to gain entry into a location. Currently, the Toronto Police service does not their own helicopter, but has access to the helicopters from York and Durham Regional Police, along with the O.P.P and the R.C.M.P.

The unit also trains with members of the Canadian Military, in particular it's special forces / anti-terrorism unit [[Joint Task Force 2|Joint Task Force 2 (JTF2)]] which works out of the [[Dwyer Hill Training Facility]] outside of Ottawa.
The E.T.F. also has a close working relationship with other police tactical teams in the Greater Toronto Area, such as the York Regional Police Emergency Response Unit (E.R.U), the Durham Regional Police Tactical Support Unit (T.S.U) and the Peel Regional Police Tactical and Rescue Unit (T.R.U).
==Equipment== The E.T.F utilizes [[Glock]] 22 and 23 9mm pistols as their sidearm. Officers also have the [[Heckler & Koch]] [[MP5-A3]] 9mm submachine gun, [[Remington 700]] bolt-action sniper rifle, Remington 870 shotgun, Mossberg M500 and the [[Colt]] [[M4 Carbine]] series of rifles, the Canadian name for it, [[Diemaco]] [[C8]] carbine ; [[Barrett M82A1]]. Less than lethal options are also at the disposal of team members such as the M18 and X26 Tasers, Pepper Spray (OC Spray) and Tear Gas (CS Gas) and Rubber Bullets or BeanBags rounds.
The main vehicles used by the team include Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptors and G.M.C Surburbans. The E.T.F also has an armoured car in their garage which can be used to rescue injured civlians or officers. The current armoured car was put into service about a year and half ago (January 2007).
Some police tactical teams have a police helicopter at their disposal. The helicopter can be used as a method of inserting team members, gathering valuable intelligence, acting as a position for a sniper/observer team and to also act as a distraction for an assault team to gain entry into a location. Currently, the Toronto Police service does not their own helicopter, but has access to the helicopters from York and Durham Regional Police, along with the O.P.P and the R.C.M.P.
